snippet: Here is where the beautiful young widow of theDauphin of France first rested her weary limbs andtried to dispel the gloom from her clouded younglife upon her return to her native land from theland of her adoption ; here was the scene of her marriage with the ill-fated Lord Darnley; here her Italiansecretary and alleged lover, Riccio, (though historiansafter a dispassionate review of the evidence in the casepro and con, are inclined to believe her innocent ofthat infamous charge, which, with all the confidentassurance of injured innocence, she always indignantlyrepelled) was murdered in her private banquet room,and, after being stabbed with fifty-six wounds,and being dragged through the Royal apartments,breathed his last ; here, to the disgust and grief of herfriends, and amid the derision and contempt of herenemies, she married Bothwell, and here, too, theprisoner of those who should have been her loyal subjects and protectors, she passed the last night beforeshe became a prisoner in the Castle of Lochleven.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: that I was sadly out, for long before there was a sign of agreeance of any sort between the court party and the lords of thesecret council, my wound was healed ; nay, indeed, had I butkent what I learned after, when Gregory came to the tower onbusiness of the Secretar's, no agreeance better than that whilkwas wrested from the queen's majesty at Lochleven by auldLindsay was like to be arrived at.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: Indeed, from the occasion of his being atthe Fast Castle, until the queen's winning out of Lochleven, hewas but seldom at Ledington, and when he did bide there hisstay was of the shortest, and was spent for the most part in converse with his father, whose counsel doubtless it was he came toseek anent the course he meant to run.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: I heardthem talk anent the state the country was in, of Carberry, of theprisoning of the queen at Lochleven, and of the likelihood of acivil broil between the two factions, the queen's party and thecongregation, yet albeit they talked of these things at somelength, I neither heard them mention Morton or Maitland, sothat when they were done and had gone out for their nags, andhad ridden away, I was as wise anent the purpose they had inbeing abroad as I was at my coming in.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: But yet some things I didlearn that touched me, among others, how that tow row, whilkthe Secretar had blown up, had ended, and how the puir queen,after being housed in Holyrude, had been conveyed away bynight, under the care of Ruthven and Lindsay, to Lochleven,to be warded for life under the een of that dour auld jade, theLady Erskine.
